context: It is found that raw materials of coconut shell contribute to developed micropore structure, narrow pore size distribution and less carbonyl group on CDC, which is better for toluene and chlorobenzene removal. There are two major reasons as follows: (1) Suitable pore size (size < 0.8 nm) leads to larger interaction on adsorbents for aromatic VOCs adsorption based on the micropore filling theory. However, the electron-withdrawing carbonyl found in CAC may reduce the surface electron density weakening the interactions between adsorbents and adsorbates. (2) According to the results of isotherms fits, it can be deduced that chlorobenzene adsorption on CDC exhibits greater affinity (Lennard–Jones potential) than toluene. Furthermore, the more polarized electrons of chlorobenzene enhance the adsorbate–adsorbent interaction, which makes chlorobenzene more easily adsorbed on the adsorbent. Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are major air pollutants in indoor environments, which significantly impact indoor quality, and thus are of growing concern to human health. Due to their common use in manufacturing processes, VOCs originate from a large variety of indoor sources including building materials, furnishings, cleaning supplies and pesticides and are frequently found indoors at levels exceeding those outdoors (EPA, 2007).

This suggests a significant difference in their behavior during adsorption processes, highlighting their relevance in the context of air quality and pollutant removal.
